ygData.subject: Re: Phenotype XML
ygData.msgSnippet: ... phenotype XML ... Yes.  The XSL writes the connection weight out along the path of the connection, which has to have an id, so to associate the weight

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> >Note that connections need to have an id, as well as a
> >"recurrent" attribute.
> >  
> >
> Do you need the ID for your XSLT? I had omitted it from my 
phenotype XML 
> since it's not really relevent. 

Yes.  The XSL writes the connection weight out along the path of the 
connection, which has to have an id, so to associate the weight text, 
there needs to a unique identifier associated with the connection.  

> I think the same applies to the 
> recurrent flag.

The XSL draws recurrent connections in red and forward ones in black, 
which is useful for visualization.  Any XSL style sheet is not going 
to be smart enough to determine whether a connection is recurrent or 
not (which, as has been pointed out, can be very complicated logic).

It is probably best to determine whether or not a given connection is 
recurrent or not, then explicitly store that information in the XML.  
This will be necessary for anyone either drawing (if you want to 
render that information visually) the network or trying to reproduce 
its functionality.  

In our framework, when a connection is designated "recurrent", all it 
really means, from an implementation standpoint, is that the output 
from the previous timestep is stored and re-input.  And because it is 
not clear whether or not some neurons should be designated recurrent, 
it is best to explicitly include that information with the XML.  If, 
for example, you sent me the XML of a network without indicating 
which connections were recurrent, I'd have to have an algorithm that 
determined that information, and my algorithm for automatically 
determining recurrency differed from yours, the networks would not 
function the same.

Derek
